Text: This strategy was much more difficult, since most of the territories, which would be best for attacking were surrounded by strong enemy troops, so I did not want to risk getting attacked over the fact that I was near an important territory. I decided to put most of my troops on Green. Specifically Green_D and Green_ C, since the territories nearest to me have a small troop count, which would make them outnumbered with their 1-1 defense. This also gives me access to Purple and Red, without putting me in a lot of danger. Blue also seemed like an easy continent to take over, which is why I chose to put my troops there too.

There was no one on blue. It was easy to just take control of the continent. This will give me extra troops right off the bat. Blue also has direct access to two other territories that I can attack and take over once I get more troops. The continents are not heavily defended and I can take over them easily.

My main goal was to be able to quickly expand while also controlling my own continent early in the game. In order to do that, I needed to have troops at Red_B and Red_C, allowing me to attack Red_A directly and control the red continent. Placing troops on Red_B and Red_C as well as Blue_B allowed me to have troops on three countries at the start, which was important. I needed to also be able to attack the purple continent in one move, which was achieved by placing troops in Red_B. I also needed to be able to attack yellow continent early on in the game, which was accomplished by placing five troops in Red_C. Additionally, placing troops at Blue_B allowed me to have troops in two continents while also allowing me to reinforce and access the blue continent in one move. In having troops in Red_C I could quickly control all of red continent. From there, I could move troops from Red_B into purple continent in one move by going into Purple_E that had be left unguarded. I could then continue to expand and place troops their quickly without much threat of attack from others. This would allow me to conquer purple fairly quickly in the game, giving me access to more troops which I could then use to move into green continent later in the game. Having troops in Blue B would not only allow for quick reinforcement early on, but it would also allow me to add troops there and then conquer blue continent early on in the game. I would move from Blue_B into Blue_A and from their move into yellow continent. This would prevent my opponents from getting a full continent as most of them are spread out and the majority of their troops are concentrated in green continent. This means they are likely to fight each other during my moves and also makes it less likely that they will be able to stop my expansion directly as I will have conquered countries that could attack my red continent directly fairly early on in the game.

I have decided to dominate my troops on purple and red majority and divide and conquer to obtain full control of green as their forces are relatively weak. I have assigned overall of 10 troops to overwhelm Green into submission. My end goal is only to possess 3 continents.

I wanted to gain control of purple since I am close to it.  I figured I could jump on over and take it with my troops.  I went all in with all 14 troops and decided to see what would happen from there. I'd like to focus only on Purple and avoid any other country for now.

In this game the way for you to when is the have the ability to have access to every single continent on the board. Seeing that red was unoccupied made me decide to put all 14 of my troops on that continent. From that position I will have the best chance to battle for troops in control of countries on every single continent. This gives me the best opportunity to win the game because I have the most access to the other continents that nobody else has. The amount of troops I have on red will also give me the opportunity to protect it from attacks that can come from purple and green. So not only is my border protected but I also can go and fight on every single continent on the game.

Yellow is my protector, everything is stored in yellow because thats the one I can travel back to. We are attacking all enemies we see thats lacking. We are taking over and grabbing everybodys things. We now won the game

I have decided to take hold of Yellow continent and to place my extra troops on Blue. The Yellow continent can only be attacked by Blue and Red Continents, so I consider it a safe position that I'll only need to put 8 troops on to defend. My plan is to take over blue and green as soon as possible, so I deployed 6 troops on Blue to get a head start there. Purple is very vulnerable so by taking over Green and Blue, my so my plan is to further expand into Purple, after I've taken over Green and blue. I don't want to start in Purple though, since it's far away from most of my troops.

My strategy in this round was to defend the blue continent from the player on the red continent, and take an opportunity to move some troops into yellow from the region in Blue A. I should be able to defend the territory in yellow against the 5 troops on that continent.

The strategy is to control red to attack all with only a single defense point with the goal of taking over blue next. Ready to defend against green at the single attack point. I wanted troops on another continent, so I placed troops on Blue B. When I control blue, I will take yellow next with still the only defense point being red A.

I wanted to spread my troops over the remaining available territories. I think this will give me the opportunity to attack opponent one at a time. With my troops being spread, I think it will allow me to slowly over take the board one territory inch by inch.

My thought process for this map is to try and keep my troops in large numbers so they are more easily able to fend themselves since the other players are working with higher troop numbers as well. I placed my troops on Red C to be able to access the Yellow and Blue territory easily along with possibly trying to attack either Red A or B for dominance over the entire red territory. I placed my purple troops on Purple E to defend from Red B and then on Purple A to be able to access the green territory along with being able to defend the territory from Blue trying to squeeze in.

Red is completely occupied, so that's out.  I'm staying away from Purple right now.  While there are many unoccupied countries, it can be attacked from 3 sides and would be hard to defend.  By surrounding the troops in Yellow, I can defeat them with greater numbers.  I would then be ready to occupy/attack Blue.  Blue can only be reached from Yellow.  Once I control those two continents, Green will be ready to be attacked. No one is coming from Purple right now. My greater numbers in Green would defeat the 6 troops there.  That would leave Red and me to fight over Purple.

Looking at this map I had opportunity to put troops on one continent and have control of that continent. That continent happen to be red so I decided to put 10 troops on the continent to be able to battle as well as protect and fortify that continent from oncoming battles against myself. From there I was going to be able to make moves on both green and purple which will give me an opportunity to add to my troop total. Another opportunity I saw was blue. On that continent I would be able to make moves there by winning two battles I will gain control of that continent and have control of two continents. This will give me a great chance of winning this game by controlling two continents and having the ability to battle to gain more control of the rest of the map.

I want to control all 4 countries of yellow and I need all of my troops to do it. I want to be able to defend yellow from an attack from blue A as well as move on to blue D, so I put 4 troops in both Yellow C and Yellow D. If I see fit, I will also be able to attack green A as well as defend from red c with my 4 troops in Yellow B.

My strategy is to overtake Purple A from grey by surrounding them with 14 troops split between Purple B and Purple E. Once I have fortified Purple continent, I can attack Green E but that will be a difficult battle. I will likely wait to engage in that battle until the grey and black players have weakened each other by fighting over Green, and maybe also red, Yellow, and Blue.

My strategy was to establish a stronghold over a continent of Green, so I put all of my troops there. I chose Green because it is the most empty continent; the yellow and blue continents in particular have a lot of enemies on them. First I will attack Green C to remove the white player from green. Then I will access Purple A and Red A. I foresee having to enter a battle with Yellow who may enter the border through Green A, however, I should have enough troops to win that battle.

I must be able to conquer Red and Purple. I want to attack again and Purple seems the most vulnerable. Almost all continents are vulnerable with Green being an initial battleground. As always I want to have strong borders and make sure no one comes into my continent or territories. I think with 12 troops I will easily be able to take control over Purple.

When I first saw the map I knew that I had to have troops on yellow and green. Yellow was an occupied so I decided to put troops on two countries. That gave me the opportunity to have access to blue and green with one move. I put troops on green in a situation where I could have access to purple within one move. Occupying these three countries on two continents gave me the ability to attack on three different fronts as well as have a battle on green to try to control that continent. I didn't see the need to have troops on blue or purple because I was going to be able to make attacks to those continents within one move as well as I have to defend myself from those continents.

My strategy is purely offensive. A player has 7 troops in the Purple continent and another has 8 in the Blue continent. I must dwindle those numbers down so I may effectively take every continent. I placed 6 troops on Red C. With only 1 player with 1 set of troops on the Red continent, I can easily take it will my large number while also having access to both Purple and Green. If the player with seven troops chooses to attack the 6 troops on the Purple continent, I can easily advance and attack them from red. If the player with 7 troops on Purple chooses to attack the Green continent instead, I also have access to that area from Red C and can take them down after the other players they attack take down their number of troops. I have placed 4 on Yellow A and 4 on Yellow D. From these areas, I can take the yellow continent and go for the 8 troops on the Blue continent. I also have access to the Green continent from Yellow D in case I need more numbers to take down the player with 7 troops on purple if that player chooses to advance to the Green continent.

My strategy was to be a beast centered on a single continent, the Blue continent. I placed 4 troops on Blue_A, 3 troops on Blue_B, 3 troops on Blue_C, and the remaining 4 troops on Blue_D.  This gives me a strong chance of overwhelming both Yellow Continent and Purple continent in order to occupy more territories.

Although Red is already occupied by 2 players I think I can make a move to overtake the continent. I'm starting with a strong force in Red A and should be able to overtake the other 2 countries in the continent. Additionally, I have support in Green. For my Green position I'm not at risk of attack right now and can afford to devote all resources to overtaking Red.

I need one troop each on Purple B, C, and D to claim the territory.  The rest of the troops are on purple A gives me the ability to defend against Blue C, Green E, and allows me to capture purple E and gain control of the purple continent.  After capturing the Purple continent this gives me the option to expand at that point to the Green continent.

I chose to occupy yellow entirely. I made this choice because it was the continent with the most unoccupied countries, didn't contain any enemy placements, and because I would be able to occupy the entire continent. I placed the number of troops on this continent in such a way that each country would have more troops than a country it could be attacked by. For example, Yellow C would have more than the 3 troops from Blue A, more than 2 troops on Yellow B since Red C has two, more than 3 troops on Yellow D, and at least one troop on Yellow A. I also wanted to ensure that I was considering the direction in which attacks were being conducted. In this instance, I could attack two continents, Blue and Green, while also being attacked by two other continents - this maximizes my battles partially. I also did not surround enemies, I just wanted to consolidate my troops in one area to make sure I had a stronghold on my territory. I chose to only occupy 4 countries rather than 7 because I figured I would be able to keep those 4 countries into future turns. Finally, I didn't think about battling one opponent at a time, I was focused more on other goals and by doing so, this goal fell by the wayside.

The first things I saw was that there was no one on red. I had to make sure and take up all three territories so that I can control and be able to defend it easily. As well as launch attacks to two continents. I figured having 9 troops on there would be a good way for me to do that.  Then I went to purple and saw only 5 troops on there. I knew that I could put the rest of my troops there. Three in one area and two in the other. I can attack and defend. Then I can make a move at green from there. These are the two continents that neighbor the one I control.

I wanted to take over red and to be able to defend it against any attacks as I need to control at least one continent completely. then I wanted to be able to start branching out while still being able to come to the defense of red if I needed to so I decided to put troops on green to try and win some battles there and then be able to slowly move across that continent while amassing troops there in order to defend against yellow, while putting a small group of troops on purple to both defend red and perhaps try to take over some of purple.

I placed all of my troops in almost all continents equally. This is the strategy is both for attacking and also defending the enemies. From Yellow_D i can attack Green_A, From Green_D i can attack Red_A, From Blue_c i can attack Purple_A, I placed 3 of my troops in Purple_E to defend the enemies and 2 troops in Blue_D for defending. As all continents having my troops i can easily conquer the continent.

I wanted to focus on one continent. Yellow is a good base and seeing they are way spread out red wont  be able to do much to be there once I have all of yellow. Initially blue a will give me the most trouble with is why I put the most at yellow c. Moving over to green while I hold yellow would be my move and I can always fall back and defend my yellow corner if need be. Unless they consolidate to purple from blue I would aim for purple over red.

Red has the optimum access compared to other continents, as controlling Red C gives you access to all other continents. Controlling red would allow me to control who can attack me and will let me spread from there. There are currently only 4 Black troops on Red C. This country will be easily taken over by the 14 troops I have surrounding it in the other 2 red countries, and once it is I'll be able to protect Red easily.

I am occupying green to attack the enemy. I'm also trying to keep my borders fortified and protected. I feel I can move around a bit more freely by placing troops on every continent and while still trying to protect my territories by having at least 1 troop on each territory. I would like to keep at least 3 troops on each continent to protect and attack if necessary.

For this map, my primary strategy to begin was to place troops in strategic positions for an excursion in to Purple. With a stronghold on Blue, the first goal would be to take over the continent Blue and then enter Purple from both sides simultaneously. The increased amount of troops in Red would allow for better defense and attack of the other Red territories during gameplay. Once Purple has been obtained, it makes a good base for entry into Green.

I wanted to place troops on two continents, placed so that I have access to multiple continents. The way to do that was to place troops on purple as well as red. The seven troops I have on red have the ability to attack the continents of blue and yellow. The seven troops on purple will be able to defend purple against blue as well as make an attack on green. This gives me lots of great chances to gain troops and control countries and even continents. That would be the best way to win the game.

My intention behind my constraints is to be able to fortify my continents of against attack from my opponents. I deployed a minimum of 2 troops per continent so as to defend my continents against attack from my opponent. I chose red, yellow and purple continents for maximum defense and also so as not to be attacked

For Red_A I choose 6 troops because I only have to deal with units of 3 defenders on that continent and I didn't want any 1 person to get control of it. I choose 6 units on Yellow A because it gives me the best attack point on that continent with no one to help if I attack the 2 units on yellow_B. And I choose 2 on blue_B to give me max defenders as well as a coin toss chance to attack and win vs blue_C

I'm trying to fortify yellow while also being able to escape to green if need be. There's a concern about blue attacking but I think the presence of Purple may keep Blue in Check, and red isn't a concern at this point.

In this map my strategy is placing 6 troops in Red continent both for attacking and defending. From Green_E i can attack Purple_A. Placing 2 troops on Yellow_B is to defend from external attack and placing 3 troops in Blue_B is also for the same reason. Here the strategy is to occupy more number of countries.

Red is unoccupied, so I am placing troops in all territories to occupy the country. I placed four troops in Green E to move into purple A. I can attack green D from my four troops in Red A. The four troops I have in red B allow me to attack Purple E. The three troops in Red C allow me to move into Yellow B.

For this map I decided to attack as much as possible. I placed 4 troops on Yellow B so that invading troops from Blue won't have a chance to gain land. Next I placed 4 troops on Purple A so that I can invade Green to gather land from Green E. Lastly I placed 6 troops, the most of my troops on Red B so that they can invade Purple E to control that land. My ultimate goal wasn't to protect country borders but to battle as many of the enemy troops as I could to gather the most land possible.

During the beginning turns I would wait to see what the black player's actions would be and either move to take countries from the yellow continent starting with C and moving to B and A to surround this player. If they do not fortify purple A with more troops or are in battles with the silver player I would look to expand to the purple countries.

I tried to maximize the available troops I would start with. I saw an entire continent open so I wanted to place everyone at least 1 on each of the Blue continent. I would have enough troops to defend that are also on Red. I could move them forward if I need them to help me out and win. Blue is my base to defend for now.

My strategy was to immediately take control of the Red Continent. This is the best strategic position because it allows me to strike at other continents. However, my primary goal here is to protect my borders. I want continue to hold the red continent, but let the other players fight it out. I will move into territories such as Yellow_B and Blue_D, but to defend my land. I want to maintain control of Red at all costs, so only invade to protect my borders. Once a continent is weak and lowly defended, I will strike quickly with my build up of troops.

I saw that continent red only had one country with enemy troops on it. That country has four black troops on it, so I decided to occupy the other two countries on the continent and put seven of my troops in each of those countries. The first thing I'm going try to do is overtake that one black country on the red continent. That will give me full control of the continent and the ability to launch attacks on every other continent on the map. I will also be able to defend the continent from any attacks from continent green. This gives me the perfect centralized location to launch attacks and start collecting troops, countries and continents.

I saw that the continent purple was empty and thought that it would be a good way for me to try to gain more troops and take control of more countries. The two countries that I occupied in purple with seven troops each have the ability to fend off attacks from blue as well as red. It also gives me the opportunity to go into the continent green if I decide to. Right now the fending off black's' attacks from blue and gaining troops in battles against them as well as the fending off blacks attacks from red and gaining troops  from them in battles is what I'm trying to think about and do.

Since Red is so useful (attack access points vs defense access points) I wanted to make sure that I had a strong presence there and could start to chip away at the other players' hold on Red. I also wanted to try and take over Yellow since my presence on Red would make it a safer bet and also gives me additional access to Blue, which would be my next target. I wanted to keep my troops close together and focus on taking over individual continents/protecting borders over spreading my troops out and fighting many battles at once.

My primary goal was to take control of Blue and Purple, which would give me access to Yellow and eventually Green. My next goal was to take control of Red because that continent would give me another direct route to Green and of the continents occupied by my opponents, it seems most vulnerable to being attacked and taken control of. I put troops in Blue, Purple, and Red to pursue these goals. Green is strongly occupied so initial attack goals are Blue D, Purple A and Red A so that I can start taking control of those continents and defending their borders. I will have to fight both of the other players to accomplish my goals.

I want to maximize the control I have over the purple continent. I am going to occupy every territory on purple, giving me 5 countries in total, and put 5 troops in purple A and purple E. This will make these countries very strong so that they can attack Green and defend from attacks from other continents. Purple b and d will be able to protect the interior of the continent and provide reinforcements. I think that by concentrating my force on Purple and not putting any troops on any other continent, I will have the best chance to win the game.

Based on the important that the Red continent holds in this game, I decided that I would place most of my troop on the Red continent as solidify my early game as much as possible. The reason I see Red as being the most power continent is as a result of it defensive capability. Because Red can only be attack by one Country, Red really only needs to be defended on one front which allows me to concentrate my power there. In addition, I decided to maximize my territory control this game due to the fact that there are many uncontested pieces that can be held with minimum effort. For instance, the pieces that I choose on the Blue and Purple continent are all pieces are at least 2 turns away from attack allowing me to collect extra pieces for those turns. In addition, by adding most of my forces to the Red continent, I am able to concentrate my forces on attacking the rest of the Red continent as well as defending it from the Green continent.

I will try to control and defend the Green continent first. I placed troops on three Green locations C, D and E this will allow me to defend or attack Purple and Red. The 1 troop in Green C is the start of holding all of the Green continent. Yellow D will have 4 troops to be able to attack both Yellow C and Green A I also have troops in Blue A to be able to attack Yellow C. Having troops place in each of these spots gives me lots of options on who to attack while still have a strong hold on Green.

I really didn't have a goal or strategy when picking my territories here I just spread them out kinda evenly because they all seemed kinda cramped and occupied already so I just went with a bunch of different options to spread myself out and cover a lot of areas at the same time. I made sure I had at least two troops on every country I controlled.

Red has many enemies, a large force would be required to claim red. By placing 10 troops on red and having backup close by, helps the odds of being able to take it over. I would have backup from the green to place into red if needed.

My early objective is to establish complete control of Red and Yellow continents, so I have placed troops on these continents to quickly accomplish that objective. From the initial landscape, I foresee battling the single Grey troop in Red_A, which I can attack from Red_B or Red_C. As the game progresses, my control of Red_C allows me to access to Blue continent, while control of Red_B gives me ready access to Purple. On Yellow continent my troops on Yellow_B will only have vulnerability to the single black troop in Yellow_C, while my Yellow_A troops may have more vulnerabilities to being attacked because of 3 black troops on Yellow_D. To deal with this, I placed 4 troops on Yellow_A and 2 on Yellow_B.

I felt it was best to disrupt and occupy both the red and purple continents. I feel they will be much easier to take over based on the troop numbers. I felt going into green was a terrible idea and yellow is already taken. Assuming i get control of red i can also attack blue before venturing into yellow.

Having no one being on blue made me want to put at least 4 on there. That would be a good number to start off with and would be able to give me a chance to defend it. Then I saw 5 on yellow and wanted to place 6 there to try and win that battle then I can control yellow and blue. Then there was 4 on red so I put 4 on there in order to make an attack there and hope to get the advantage eon that continent as well. This strategy gives me troops on 3 continents with the chance to control all of them if I attacked successfully.

I want the option to attack either red or purple A. I want a high concentration of troops. I want overwhelming numbers and believe that red would be the easiest continent to obtain. If the occupied green territory comes at me then I also want to have numbers to defend.

My top goal is to control the green continent. The grey player has armies in green c that I will need to wipe out. I have surrounded Green C with armies that are at least size four and put all 14 of my troops on the continent in case they need reinforcements. There is no direct threat at the moment from red a or purple a, so I don't need to concentrate on protecting the borders of Green. I would normally be wary of an attack from yellow d, but I think the players on Yellow will be busy fighting each other. If I stay away from yellow and blue, I should be able to avoid those fights and focus on taking over Green.

I put most of my troops in the purple e position since that is being accessed by red, green and a couple spots in purple. The purple d and c spots hold 1 of my troops each so that I can get the max territory boost. And then I put some troops in the green position to the north since there is only 1 green position taken there and I want to take over red and I can also attack the single green territory without using my purple troops.

When the board was presented to me I saw that I could make some good moves on continent Red.  There was country occupied with 4 black troops. I knew that I could win battles versus that country and control the entire continent if I placed all of my troops around that country, giving me access to the countries that would allow me to win the troops needed to better my standing in the game. The total control of Red allows me to attack every single continent on the board. This gives me the best chance at winning more battles.

I figured that since no one was occupying yellow, it was a good place to start. I put troops in Yellow C and Yellow D. I could attack Blue D from Yellow C and have that, but at the same time, I wanted to be able to defend Yellow. I needed enough troops on Yellow C to travel and protect it from Blue A, which grey holds. From Yellow, I could access Blue and possibly gain some ground. On green, I wanted to have enough troops to attack Green D, take it over from Black, and hopefully have enough to defend against Red A. I decided 5 troops on green would be enough to do this. I tried to make sure that wherever I had troops at, there were more of my troops than neighboring enemy troops. This led me to put at least 3 troops in each of my territories.

My strategy was to control at least 6 countries so I could get 2 troops during my turn. Then, I targeted what I thought were weak territories across the continents but without spreading my troops too thin.

I plan on taking red as soon as possible. It would act as a good staging ground for attacking purple, green, and yellow. After taking red, i would fortify Red A in order to defend against green and then attack yellow to take as much of that as possible. My goal is to get as many continents as possible to maximize my troops while fortifying any connections between continents.

My strategy was to establish a stronghold over a continent. I placed 1 troops on all countries on green continent. So the Green continent is mine. Next I placed troops on the other continent. I placed as much as troops as I can. So I can attack others.

Five troops were deployed to Purple_E to establish presence on Purple. Two troops were deployed to Red_B to fortify it against an attack from Red_A. Three troops were deployed to Red_C for fortification and attack on Red_A to gain control of the Red continent. Two troops were deployed to both Blue_B and Yellow_B to establish a presence on both the Blue and Yellow continents. With the placements of these troops, no player will have control of the Yellow, Blue, or Purple continents. This will decrease the number of troops recruited in each rival's turn. I can place more troops in Yellow_B, Blue_B, and Purple_E during future turns to maintain a stronghold in at least one country on each of the continents before I attack other countries on those continents.

I give all my strength to the country of Red C from which I can attack the yellow and blue continents which I should be able to take over and. While I attack yellow and Blue I should still be able to keep hold of Red C and expand on Red since I started all of my troops there. After I conquer Red I can try to attack either the green continent or the purple one.

Yellow gives me access to both Green and Blue, so I wanted to control that continent.  There is only 1 grey troop on Yellow at this moment, so by putting my troops in the other three countries, I can control Yellow.  Green will give me access to both Red and Purple, so that is another continent I aim to control.  I have surrounded the enemy in Green.  It will be easy to defend Green from Red, but I am concerned about Purple's troops.

For me when I looked at the map there was only one place that I wanted to put my 14 troops. I thought the best strategy for me was to split up the 14 troops into the two unoccupied country countries on the continent with the color red. I put seven troops in each of the two countries, giving me an opportunity to battle the one country that has four troops on it on that continent and try to win total control of the continent. Once I went total control of the continent I would be able to launch attacks on every other continent on the board. With a total number of 14 troops that should give me a great opportunity to launch good attacks against continents on the opposite side with the colors yellow and blue. While also launching attacks against continents right next to me with the colors purple and green. This gives me more battles to fight in a greater chance of winning troops in controlling more countries and continents.

I feel like my occupying country C on red gives me a great chance to control the board. I placed all 14 of my troops on there. That way I can battle to the other countries on red and gain control of the whole continent. Since both grey and black have countries on Red, I will get to defeat both of them at the same time with this strategy. Once I do that, then I will have many troops to launch attacks on all other continents. Red is the one continent that gives you the ability to launch offensive attacks against countries in every other continent. If you are successful, then you have the best chance to win the game by controlling the board.

I plan on taking red as soon as possible and using it as a staging area to attack other continents from. Red only has one entrance so it would be easy to mass up 7 troops there to defend it. My plan is to enter purple as quickly as possible to start taking land. Once purple is taken, i would set up defenses at purple A and move my troops to attack green. My focus is limiting the places the enemies can engage from.

My strategy is to control Red and to take over Yellow and then defend both continents because they are poorly defended. I plan to keep my troops piled up as much as possible and the easiest route to me looks like attacking Red_B from Red_C and then using minimal troops to attack Yellow B from Red A, while keeping most on Red to defend in case the troops on the Purple continent move towards me through Green. Controlling Red would keep me supplied with troops and it is less vulnerable to attack. I considered trying to weaken the troops on Blue, but I thought it'd be better to build up my army on Red and defend from the troops coming from Blue to Yellow that way.

Red was empty, so I took it and took the entire continent. Since the only continent who can attack Red is the green, I put most of my troops in Red A to defend if necessary or possibly to attack Green D if they don't attack me first. . I placed a few units in Red B to attack Purple E since there's only one unit sitting there. Since units on the blue and yellow continents can't attack me yet, for the moment, I'm not worrying about them. Once I've taken either Green or Purple and expanded my territory, I will then put more troops into Red C to threaten their western border limiting the number of units they can seen into Purple and green.

My strategy was to establish complete control over the red continent by spreading 9 troops over all the territories on that continent and placing my troops where they can easily access purple, green, or blue. The red continent has the ability to attack all other continents, so I thought it made the most sense to completely gain control of this continent. I also put 5 troops in A to help me attack the Black player there.

I control Blue and have a good start on Purple. I put extra troops in Purple to be able to move them to attack the one enemy on the Purple Map. I will move my troops up the Purple continent to attack Purple A, I can also attack from Blue C. In this game I will try to get both Blue and the Purple Maps first then move on to the other colors after I have secured the Blue and Purple Maps.

I saw that the continent purple was unoccupied. I think that I would be able to make moves by putting seven troops on both purple a and purple e. From there I would be able to launch fast attacks on Green. I would also be able to fend off some attacks from Red as well as Blue. By fighting these battles I put myself in a position to be able to maximize my opportunity at winning the game. The more battles I get into, the more troops and countries I collect. I also have set myself up to protect my border from the attacks that might be incoming and have kept my troops concentrated in one place.

My strategy is to occupy most of the Purple continent, hopefully kicking the person there out, so I have placed 3 troops on Purple_A, 3 on Purple_B, and 4 on Purple_D in order to show a great presence there. I decided to put 4 troops on the Red continent on Red_B in hopes that I can get lucky enough to push the other occupier out. This seems optimal for focusing on the Green continent.

Considering that Purple has only one army, it is easier to attack. There are not many enemy troops in blue and yellow, so you can try to attack while attacking purple. But don't forget to do a good job of defense to prevent your home from being stolen.

The strategy for the provided board is to control the purple continent, as the purple continent is the only unoccupied territory on the board. The goal is to maintain a strong defense to discourage attack by other players, and to wait for troop reinforcements to give enough of a numerical advantage to permit attack against either the green or blue continent, depending on game condition. Surrounding enemy territories is irrelevant; the goal is simply to eliminate units from each continent as quickly as possible. Maximizing the number of countries at the beginning of the game is somewhat important with this board; three purple territories can safely be occupied with only one troop each. Keeping all forces grouped together makes both the probabilities of successful attack and defense higher than keeping troops spread across the available countries on the board. Minimizing the number of battles fought is additionally important; any battle should advance the goal of seizing new territories, but defensive battles should be avoided at all costs to minimize troop losses. Keeping 5 troops on the two purple territories that can be attacked should reduce the likelihood of other players successfully attacking. Placing units on any other continent is poor strategy; maintaining as many units as possible on the two vulnerable purple territories is a better use of troops, both to reduce the chance of receiving attacks and to permit an attack to be made against the green continent.

Red was completely unoccupied, so I took all the territory there in large numbers in the hopes of being able to maintain control. Then with my remaining troops, I looked at other countries that had weak territories around it. I would start strengthening those territories first in the hopes of expanding further.

When I checked out the board they were a lot of options for me to put troops on places that would give me an opportunity to be able to move in with some battles. For me the best option turned out to be red since it was unoccupied. I fortified my presence on that continent by placing all 14 troops on there. That gives me total control and a way for me to protect myself on that continent. It also put me in a place where I could attack various continents with the troops I have on there in order to win more battles in advance to the continents that I don't have troops on. To me this was the best strategy with less risk and higher reward for me to win the game.

It is time to spread out the troops to defend territories and troops. That is the best plan of action is to defend borders and territories for all of the continents. The more troops you have the more of a successful battle. I still need to put more troops spread throughout the continents.

Looking at the red continent, I see it's the best place to hold a defensive strategy. Since Green is really the only threat to them. I need to take over Red C, which should be an easy feat with 7 troops vs their 4. Once I have the full red, I'll start moving for Green and if I can secure the border there, then no one can provoke me in red.

Overall I was trying to fill Red. It seems like the best continent to occupy just from the ability to travel and attack any of the other continents in a single move. It allows to me to build up forces right behind my others troops in the pathway to move to the new one. I can then build my army going forward with a strong army staying on the Red zone that I can move anywhere quickly. I wanted troops in at least two continents so I placed troops in Yellow B and Blue B.

I want to gain a stronghold of the blue continent and take over blue d from black, so I have taken the countries around it. The red continent is weakly defended by grey so I want to have a force of 3 troops in red c that could fend off and attack from red a or impending attacks from the grey armies on green if they move onto the red continent. My ultimate goal is to control all of blue and then spread to yellow and purple, but having troops in red gives me a good backup plan if this fails.

With Yellow approaching my territory on Green, I wanted to protect that border. I was also looking to take over Red since it was pretty much unoccupied. I was also protecting against the threat from Purple to the South.

My strategy was to place my troops on red to occupy the entire continent. From there I can defend and attack green and purple easily. I also placed my troops on blue A, so I can try to attack other player on that continent. This would also give me access to yellow continent. I tried to avoid yellow continent, because one player has large number of troops there already. I wanted to avoid battling with large number of troops at this stage.

For this map I wanted to find a placement that would allow me to both defend and attack in such a way that I could "cut off" access to my main continent. Yellow seemed the best choice here as it was completely open and only accessible by blue and red so I wanted the majority of my troops on yellow. I intentionally left the space directly next to blue open as it is surrounded on 3 sides and my next placement was a hyper aggressive 5 troops at Blue D for offense. This would allow me to capture Blue B or Blue C with relative ease. If this worked out I would have full control over blue and yellow and only Red would have a line to attack me.

With this map there was a lot of strategy to think about. Purple was empty so that was easy for me to pick as a continent that I wanted to put troops on. I wanted to put troops on countries that would allow me to protect purple against red as well as troops that allow me to go over and battle in green. So I put a total of nine troops on purple, with five for defending against red and four for attacking green. The other five troops that I had I put on red. The empty country on red gives me an opportunity to try to battle the two occupied countries on there as well as having the ability to attack both the yellow and blue continents from that one country. Occupying Red C maximizes my opportunities to gain land and troops.

My strategy was to put almost all my troops in 2 purple counties to seal off borders and prepare for a move to the green. The lower part of green is thin so may be able to hold those later on. Red B had 4 troops so I had to put 7 in Purple E for a pending battle. Since I put 3 troops in Purple A, this means I had 10 troops defending the continent.

I placed troops in Red B to be able to attack Purple E and potentially open up the country so I could more easily occupy it and join the troops I have placed in Purple A which I placed to defend against an attack from troops in Green and to be able to attack as well to block any potential total occupation. I placed troops in Blue A and Blue D to attack Yellow and take away total occupancy from my opponent. I placed troops in Green B to prevent future total occupation of Green by my opponent. I placed the most troops in Blue to facilitate total occupation in the future. I also placed troops in Red C to defend against total occupancy and to be able to attack Yellow and try to remove total occupancy from my opponent.

When I looked at the map I saw that everything on red was occupied. That made me not really want to put anything on there as I could not. I knew that if I put a good amount of troops on Green then I would be able to launch attacks to overtake that continent. Then I could move to red or purple from there. More likely red and overtake that.  Next I was going to go to blue and put enough troops to launch an attack there and overtake that continent as well. That would give me two continents in my arsenal. Then I will have trooos to defend two continents with a great chance to take over a third. To me that is the best way for me to try and make an assault and control the most territories on these continents. Pick fights that are to my advantage with the number of troops.

My strategy was to put myself in a strong position to take over a whole continent, which I did with red. However, I also wanted troops across the entire map so I would have easy access to each opponent, and also to try and block them from controlling an entire territory.

I want to control the yellow continent so I took its three open territories and surrounded the other player there. I also need to be able to defend from an attack from blue a and red c. I also have the ability to move to the blue and green continent where there are some unoccupied territories.

My strategy at first was to divide and conquer; to try to put my starting pieces on every continent, so that I would have sure access to everything. Then when I took a closer look at my opponent's strategies, I notices that it would be unwise, since they all had most of their troops close together, in a high number, so that they would have less to risk. I saw that yellow had weak defense, so I decided to place the majority of my troops there, since statistically I would be able to conquer Yellow_B fairly easily, and then all of Yellow would be occupied by me. I would also have access to attacking both Green and Blue from this stance. However, I didn't want for all  of my troops to be in Yellow, since that would also be too risky, I decided to place my remaining troops in Green_D, since I would have easy access to Red, but I would also have to chance to conquer Green_C, which would give me access to Purple as well.

My first positioning was with yellow, the unoccupied continent. It was threatened by a 3 piece position from blue and a two-piece position from red, so in adding pieces I wanted to add enough pieces to prevent blue and red from advancing (more than 2 against red's border, more than 3 against blue's). Once yellow was fortified from attacks, I looked for the nearest continent I'd like to occupy, which was green; I decided this somewhat arbitrarily, mainly because green was nearby and the pathway to green from yellow didn't need defending since the arrow only went one way. I positioned the of my troops on green rather than on the borders of yellow so I didn't have to waste a move before attacking green. The amount allocated to green was the amount of pieces I had remaining, five, which should be enough to take out one side of green and potentially another as well if I move additional pieces from yellow over. The broader plan would be to secure both yellow and green and then advance from there.

My strategy is to get control of the Red continent as soon as possible by putting a large number of troops in Red A and Red B so I can overpower the black troops in Red C.  I also wanted to make sure I protect Red's borders by controlling Green D.  Overall, I think that once I control the Red continent and Green D, I have access to every other continent on the board and can manage my expansion plans better.  I also saw an opportunity to aggressively pursue taking over the Green continent by having troops in Green B who can attack the enemies in the remaining Green countries.  I feel Green is a very active continent, but if I start with 6 troops there are can easily move more from Red, I have an excellent chance of overtaking Green.

I placed 4 units on Purple D because it would be a stronghold for that continent, stronger than the 1 force that's next to it, and not intimidated by the closest continent (red) or even the further continents (blue) or (green). Placing 4 on Green D is also a stronghold which is stronger than any territory in it's own continent or the red one next to it. Placing 6 troops at Blue C is stronger than the other blue territories and could rival the neighboring Purple A with 5. I think all of these positions set me up well for taking over an entire continent because I have a strong presence that can't be immediately squelched on the three continents that are touching Purple.

My strategy was to occupy purple continent entirely first. I wanted to avoid green and red continents since my opponents already placed large number of troops there to defend. I wanted to keep my troops together to defend well. I didn't want to place my troops on any other continent yet, so I can attack one at a time and take my time to expand my territory.

When I looked at the board I saw that yellow was an empty continent. I want to have 8 troops split between two of the countries on that continent to claim it. Those countries would be ones that are able to attack the continent blue as well as the continent green. Then I saw that purple had a country that was directly able to attack green as well as fend off attacks from green. I thought that putting 6 troops on that purple country gave me a chance to go after green again and fend off attacks. Purple also gives me chances to battle within the continent for troops.

Red is the continent I want, but is currently overtaken by my enemies. All my troops will be put on green and I will then try to invade the red. There is currently a large amount of black troops on green that are protecting the country leading to the red continent, so I will focus on that one territory with all my forces. As a result, I can't put troops on any open continent other than green. If I end up not being able to invade Red, I will still be able to build a fortress on green and invade purple.

Honestly, this looks like a straight up arms race. I'm going to be defensive here. The occupants in Red and Green continents looked geared up for war and I am happy to let them fight it out. Purple is the lowest defended and most up for grabs continent. I would like to establish a foothold and strike from there. Everyone right now is dispersed which makes me uneasy.

This strategy is primarily defensive, occupying the purple country while also grouping together six troops  on red c which should be enough to successfully overtake red. On purple A I stationed 3 troops, which is just enough to prevent blue from invading, while on purple E I did the same to fortify against red but with 5 troops instead. This gave me 8 total troops defending purple. The green continent was my main target due to purple's ability to travel to green, but since green was already occupied by a large number of enemy troops, I put my own large bulk of troops on purple in the hopes of being able to defeat them later. This is not an ideal scenario because there are many enemy countries primed to attack purple, the one continent I decided to occupy, but the overarching strategy would be to overtake green and then utilize those two continents, purple and green, to fend off any overeager enemy attackers from red and yellow.

I wanted to put troops in both the Yellow and Green continents, they were the least populated and I did not think it would hurt to set up camp there. I put troops in the green continent so it could potentially battle red which is a very unprotected continent. I stayed a bit away from purple out of fear from a very protected country, but I think that could be counteracted if I gain control of the red continent. Despite the 8 number of troops gray has put on the blue continent, I wanted to flush it out a bit so I could potentially have a chance and then protect the cycle of the yellow and green continent to make purple chase their tail if they go for the blue continent hard

I want to regroup my army. I wanted to move further west while containing my armies back together again. I think it was a good method to thin my army out a bit but at the same time it puts me at a greater risk for conflict. I felt that bringing my armies together again would give me a better chance for success against an attack. I did want to continue moving around the board in hopes that my attacks would move in a different direction. I believe this method will be beneficial in case an attack comes my way.

I picked green because I wanted to play defense. That continent looked like it would be perfect for that. I want to occupy blue and purple because it would be good to defend from the other areas.  I want to protect green and not fight if I don't have to.

I wanted to make sure that I use a defensive strategy for the game, so I wanted to only be on the green continent. I am already surrounding the weaker grey troops on the green continent with 14 troops in Green B so it will be easy to take over the continent and protect it. I have also stayed away from the borders so it will be harder to attack my troops.

I am going to control of the red continent by taking the three red continents and fortifying Red A. From there I will probably hit blue b. The blue continent looks ripe for the taking, since I can isolate grey's troops there. Considering I hold a strong defensive position on Red, I don't need troops on any other continent to start the game.

I split my troops amongst purple, since it was the least occupied so far and I would have the easiest time taking it over, and since red has so many troops looking to attack on its borders. I placed a large number of troops on Yellows access point to red to further potentially stall or put a stop to its aggressive play. I didn't want to put all my troops in purple as well so yellow seemed to make since with its relationship to red. I would also easily outnumber the troops in yellow this way. I felt I secured purples borders thoroughly against blue also outnumbering the troops at that access point. I felt comfortable placing groups of three across it since green would have to advance countries first before attacking, meaning I initially would only have to be concerned with red and blue.

My opponents have heavily taken on two of the countries (Blue and Yellow) so I will avoid those two zones and allow them to fight each other and deplete their numbers in battles. If I set up a good number of troops in Red I can attack green within 1 move and hopefully prevail. If I also set up a good amount of troops in purple I can overtake the camps there rather easily.  This strategy should give me control over red, purple and Green without losing too many of my troops.  Meanwhile the other opponents will be forced to battle each other as they can only move from the left of the map towards the right and I will have secured the right side and will be moving left to take on what's left of their numbers. I can protect my control over Red by leaving one troop and continue to do this as a conquer and move across the map toward the left side.

In this setup, my short-term goal is to conquer the Purple continent and defend my troops on adjacent continents that have access to the purple continent. Therefore, I have placed troops in all but one country on the purple continent. That country is currently controlled by the player with black pieces but has only two troops present. I have access to attack that country via Purple_A, _B and _D as well as Red_B. My vulnerabilities are chiefly in Purple_A, Blue_C and Red_B. I have placed three troops in Purple_A and Red_C to guard against invasion. I am initially focusing on the player with black pieces.

I went in the ways the arrows go, so therefore soon as my people attack they are regrouping and hitting another continent. As they are growing bigger to take over everybody, they might not be able to back track, But I've made a way too back track and hit every continent again just to be sure. It starts off at yellow, we move to blue, then we travel to purple, up to green, and attack red then were back at yellow doing it all over again. This is Our Country.

I wanted to have nearly complete control of one continent, which in this case is Blue. I wanted to be able to access Yellow in one move and hopefully battle them when the time is right. I wanted to avoid battle because I like to see how battle plays out before I throw my hat in the ring. Once I take out the small enemy hold in the south of Blue, I'll have complete control of the continent and have access to Purple in 1 move with enough troops to begin battle or defend, if necessary.

I am going to try to build a stronghold in Green. I need at least 2 troops to defend Green_B. I am evenly distributing troops on Green_A, Green_D, and Green_E to protect its borders. I need to surround the black troops in Green_C to prepare for battle against them. Once I have defeated Green_C, I will invade either Purple or Red.

My main idea is to overwhelm the single grey troop in Red A so I have control of the Red continent. There is only one path to get to red, and that is through green. If I can take over red A with mass troops I can easily hold Red and then spread out to purple, blue, green, and yellow. To achieve this I have split all of my troops evenly between Red B and C which surrounds Red A.

I am going to wipe out the grey armies on green c. This should be pretty easy, since all 14 of my troops are on green's other 4 countries and have cut off grey's reinforcements. The only immediate threat to my control of green after that looks to be from yellow d, which grey also controls, so I'm keeping 4 troops in Green A to protect my border. My goal is to gain control of the green continent and then push onto red or purple or both. I am taking a safe position here, since I'll only fight grey at the start of the game.

I wanted to control a continent completely for the bonus troops. I picked yellow for this because no other players had troops on it, so I wouldn't need to fight much. I took control of all four of its territories. I fully intend to spread out from here to Blue and Green, but only once my borders are secure. To help get there, I put all of my troops on Yellow to start. I hope that black and grey will fight each other and allow me more time to build up and nip off pieces of their territory.

It's not possible to immediately take over an entire continent in this map, but there are 3 continents with only 1 occupied country. These are Blue, Purple and Red. I chose to place my troops in all the unoccupied countries in Blue and Red. The Purple continent lies between Blue and Red. This is the next continent I plan to occupy, after first claiming the whole of the Blue and Red continents. I gave 3 troops to each country that can either attack or defend. Blue_b received 2 troops because it's only exposed to a Red country that I occupy (Red_c) and enemy troops from Blue_b. Blue_b is surrounded by my own troops and I'm hoping it will quickly be defeated.

With all my military on red split between two countries, it will allow me to take over the continent quickly. There is already 4 enemies within the red borders from the black player, but the rest of their troops are spread throughout the map. Red should be easy to take over with no worry of back up from black, which allow my offensive tactics to proceed from there. Green has potential of being the first next continent to take over since it is sparsely defended. I will avoid fighting on Yellow since there are many enemy troops on there.

To me having only one continent with troops of mine is the best way for me to be able to start moving across and take over more territories and continents. The continent that I picked was blue. I am able to split up my 14 troops and place them on two territories on blue. Through these spots I am able to make moves on both purple and yellow with an abundance of troops to take them over. So I put 7 in each spot which gives me more than any other troop level that I would be facing.

My strategy was to establish a stronghold over the blue continent while also maximizing the mobility of my troops over the course of the game so that I can expand my army quickly in the early stages of the game. First I placed troops on two countries in blue,  blue A and blue B. These 8 troops give me some control over continent blue and ensures I have access to yellow. I also placed one set of troops on yellow B so  that I could try to attack the black troops on yellow multiple ways, from either yellow B or blue A.  I placed some other troops on red, so that I can try to attack any troops that enter purple E or the grey troops on red. This strategy also gives my 4 countries which will increase the amount of additional troops I get each turn.

It seems many players were already trying to entrench themselves in other continents, expect for green. My strategy then is to try to hold Green as quickly as possible. I don't normally like to try to hold Asia so early on, but with the current set-up of the board I have few other spaces to make such a play. Holding Green would require eliminating the player in Green E quickly, so I build up a large force adjacent to Green E. This also will set the stage for me to move into the Red continent next. In order to protect the flank of my Green continent, I also kept a larger force in Green A, the only Green territory that would be vulnerable to attack besides E and D.

My strategy was to use the red continent as my home base. I knew I needed to have all my troops on the Red continent, even though it limits the number of countries I can control. There were two empty countries on Red so I put at least 5 troops on both of them. From there I will have access to continents purple, blue, yellow. This maximizes my ability to gain more troops by battling on those continents. It also gives me the ability to protect red from incoming attacks because I will have 14 troops on that continent. Eventually I am going to battle the one enemy troop that is on the other country in Red and take over the entire continent, which will then give me access to green as well. I can do this whenever I want, since I have the other country surrounded.

Based on the map, the majority of the continents were already taken so the only one left was the Green continent. I want to make sure I protect the borders of green. I wanted to set up a defense between the Red continent and Yellow continent, while making sure the overall continent is well defended.

I want to control the yellow continent. It is beneficial for me to occupy it in its entirety, so I put all 14 of my troops on the continent. I also need a strong force of 4 troops in yellow b and c to protect from a potential attack from the black player's troops in red c and the grey player's troops in blue a and strong force in yellow d to attack green a. By keeping my troops close together, I hope to be able to win many battles in this game.

Once again, I think a good strategy is to focus on one continent at first because the bonus for occupying an entire continent early on outweighs any other benefit that I can think of. With this in mind, I then focused on occupying the easiest continent to take over, which I assume is Purple, as there is only one player and it isn't occupied by many troops. I plan on attacking early so I can claim all of Purple for the bonus.

Looking at the map I saw that I had an opportunity to occupy 3 continents with a good number of troops on each. Then I would have 4 on blue to make a move there as well as have access to yellow from one move

Tried something a bit more different. If I start out on the smaller controlled I may have a better chance. I also have direct arrows to the rest of the continent from blue and yellow. If I take over yellow Id definitely me able to move to green and my focus would then be red over purple.

Red has no enemy forces, so I placed troops on each square of Red to fully control the continent.  Not only does this get me the bonus for controlling Red, it provides an excellent base as the other four continents can all be attacked from Red.  Red itself can only be attacked from Green_D, so Green_D was also occupied and a large number of troops placed the to defend Red.  The plan is to then attack Blue as it is lightly defended by gray.  Six troops have been placed on Red_C in readiness for this attack.  Yellow, which only has black troops at this point, can also be attacked from Red_C.  Yellow is more heavily defended however, so this is a longer term plan.

The strategy for the provided board is to control the red continent, as the red continent has the strongest position on the board, and then proceeding to attack the blue continent to increase troop reinforcements as quickly as possible. Red A is the only red territory requiring defense, allowing all additional troops to be used to attack Blue. Once blue is defeated, only two territories, Red A and Blue D require defense, allowing an attack against Yellow or Purple on later turns. Surrounding enemy territories is irrelevant; the goal is simply to eliminate units from each continent as quickly as possible. Maximizing the number of countries at the beginning of the game is not an important goal; spreading out troops makes them too vulnerable to attack from other players. Keeping all forces grouped together makes both the probabilities of successful attack and defense higher than keeping troops spread across the available countries on the board. Minimizing the number of battles fought is additionally important; any battle should advance the goal of seizing new territories, but defensive battles should be avoided at all costs to minimize troop losses. Controlling all of the red continent early provides the best advantage, only Red A can be attacked, and so it is the only point where defense is required, affording offensive opportunities against all other continents while minimizing the number of troops required to be left on defense. Keeping all troops on the red continent affords the opportunity to attack the purple, green, blue, or yellow territories, while only requiring the defense of one red territory. By protecting Red A with 10 troops I will also be protecting the borders of red which will afford a better chance to receive more reinforcements for controlling the continent.

I will sit pretty here on red with all of my troops split between its three countries for some time. I may go after blue b first. The blue continent is weak with only three grey troops on it. I want to be able to defend from any type of future attack from green d and then maybe move on yellow b down the road, which is why I'm keeping five troops in red A. I want my armies to stay consolidated while having the option to invade many other continents.

I want to take over and defend the green continent. I decided to place the troops on the borders, which are vulnerable to enemy attacks. I also decided to place one extra troop on the countries that surround Green E so it should be easy to conquer that territory within my first turn, depending on whether I go before that opponent or not and s/he has the chance to move back up troops there. If successful, I can then simply move/rearrange my troops to cover all countries in the green continent, play defense and gain the big troop bonus.

The strategy for the provided board requires taking control of the red continent as soon as possible, and then proceeding to attack the blue continent to increase troop reinforcements as quickly as possible. Surrounding enemy territories is not important; the goal is simply to eliminate enemy units from each continent as quickly as possible. Maximizing the number of countries at the beginning of the game is not an important goal; spreading out troops makes them too vulnerable to attack from other players. Keeping all forces grouped together makes both the probabilities of successful attack and defense higher than keeping troops spread across the available countries on the board. Minimizing the number of battles fought is additionally important; any battle should advance the goal of seizing new territories, but defensive battles should be avoided at all costs to minimize troop losses. Seizing control of the red continent early provides the best advantage, only Red A can be attacked, and so it is the only point where defense is required, affording offensive opportunities against all other continents while limiting the number of troops required to be left on defense to 7. Keeping all troops on the red continent affords the opportunity to attack the purple, yellow, or blue territories, while only requiring the defense of one red territory. Protecting the borders of red will afford a better chance to receive more reinforcements for controlling the continent.

I placed my troops in such a way as to give myself the ability to attack bordering territories while somewhat defending my early vulnerabilities. Specifically, I placed troops into six different territories with a minimum of two troops per territory. The troops are arranged to give me the opportunity to primarily focus my attacks on only one player's troops on the green continent and the purple continent by having my troops initially control two to three territories in each of these continents. At the same time, I have opportunities for expansion into both the red and the blue continents by having a contingency of troops on blue and a route to attack red via green. Defensively, I have avoided coastal territories that can be attacked from other continents but cannot reciprocally attack and have placed a higher number of troops on the green-D territory that has coastal access from red.

This was a bit hard to figure out. My first thought was that I don't want to have to fight at Red so I should stay away from it. I then looked to see where I could set up reasonable fights and Yellow seemed like the best choice here. I placed a rather overwhelming amount of troops on the two available yellow tiles so that I could focus on capturing the continent which gives me good access to the less defended blue continent. I also placed a force on purple just to slowly expand there because it is unoccupied and I need to have a few countries occupied.

I decided to put 6 troops in Red B and 8 in Blue A. For me this set up is the best one for a long-term success. Putting those troops in blue gives me the opportunity to win the battle in blue add to my troop count which would give me a good amount to go into yellow and try to win battles in there. I would have control of a continent and looking to gain control of another continent with overwhelming troop support. When it comes to Red B, I thought that it would be best to put six troops on there. I could win the battles between the two countries on red and gain more troops. Then I could go to purple or green and try to battle those countries on those continents. If I can secure the battles in red and in blue, then I would have control of two continents with the vast amount of troops to give me the opportunity to attack yellow, purple and green. If it all plays out correctly it should give me a great chance to win the game.

I put my troops on the purple continent and no other continents, in the 4 Purple countries other than Purple A. Considering my troop placement here, with 5 in Purple B and 5 in Purple E, there are no real immediate enemies that cause me to fear for my troops. I will squash the grey army in purple a and control the entire continent. Green D will then have to defend against my attacks.

I was first interested in occupying countries with the lowest number of access points yellow and blue. Since I could fully occupy Yellow with the maximum number of troops needed to fend off the maximum amount of attacks that could occur during one turn (4 troops) plus two extra troops to keep the borders safe, I then turned to Blue. Since I fully occupied Yellow, I only needed to worry about an attack from Red although now I'm realizing that I probably need to worry about an attack from the other players occupying Blue, right?
